bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, February 6, 1899

div1.p: Carter discusses quarantine and maritime sanitation in Cuba. Carter has already had yellow fever, so he does not fear infection.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, February 6, 1899
div1.opener:
Grand Hotel Pasaje
______
THE LARGEST AMERICAN FIRST-CLASS HOTEL
ON THE ISLAND OF CUBA
______
LATEST IMPROVEMENTS. ELEVATOR, ELECTRIC LIGHTS
FRONTING THE PARKS
______
DIAZ, GONZALEZ & Co., Proprietors
Havana, Feb 6 1899
Address: “U. S. Marine-Hospital Office.”
not hotel
Dear Mother:
div1.p:
I am writing by a candle in spite
of the magnificence depicted above - to be sure a “facts
close candell parafina Americana” as I am infor-
med. So I will not write much,

I tried to get to North River from Washington, & indeed had
my plans laid to go there Sunday - reaching you about mid-
night, but had to leave for this place that day. And
it was well I did so, & had been very much
better had I left 3 days earlier as a decidedly
annoying complication has arisen by an assumption
of some of my functions by Gen'l Ludlow, just before
I arrived. It will come out all straight for me but
I wish well it had been avoidable.

I wished much to see you. I hoped I could have stayed to
the downtrain Wednesday, nearly three days.
Well I am here for how long I cannot say. Until I
complete the organization of the Quarantine & Maritime
sanitation in this Country. The work is hard & doubt-
ful, not only against the malign forces of nature - but the
Jealousies: vanities & general contrariness of men,
C1
B21
& of all things I like peace: Old Commodore Crom-
well, Captain of the Party is the only man I have
seen who is working without thought of himself.

Henry was fairly well- convalescent from Grippe - when
I left N. O., on tomorrow fortnight week, Laura was not eating
enough, but had not been sick. Ned, was well &
was to take his first lesson in the violin. Laura Sr. was
well. She had a dreadful spell on her arrival at N. O.
but had been very well for some time.

I spent one night Saturday - at Ned's house & saw
Helen & Sylvia- I also waited there one night with
Henry Carter a long time & saw him for a little
while, I went also to see Jim Baylor - of Caroline
- whom I used to know & like so well at the University.
Now I am glad I had yellow fever, I would be here any-
way & otherwise I would be afraid. One has it but once.
My garden in N. O. was just beginning to be interesting.
Dear love to all at North River & I judge that I will
see you & Laura & the children there next fallsummer.
Again dear love, & God bless you
div1.closer:
Your Affec'ate son H. R. Carter. I am thinking how much work, good work much of it,
your sons have done in the world. It is a privilege to
have been able "to serve ones generation by the grace of God.
H. R. C.
